pros: Family atmosphere, great pay, available overtime

review_title: Horrible Pay for the Job and Overworked
pros: Helping people who are really sick schedule the tests and appointments they need. Getting to know the patients and their families.
cons: You get paid nothing. You are chart prepping, scheduling patients for upcoming appointments, calling central scheduling, and I was getting paid under $16. They overwork you and you are not allowed to get overtime.

pros: Lots of overtime, gift shop in hospital

job_title: In Patient Wound Care Nurse in Easton, PA
pros: Non-profit. Goal is to help patients; not put extra money in shareholders' pockets. Friendly, caring culture. Employees are expected to be nice to one another. Provide bonuses to all staff during Covid and after Covid provided inflation bonuses. Excellent health care benefits. Need to stay in St. Luke's Network unless get out of network exception- which is not that hard to do.
cons: I do not feel that the medical residents are adequately supervised by the attending physicians. The attending hospitalist physicians have too many residents to supervise/oversee.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Stroudsburg, PA
pros: Clean work environment Benefits for part timers Food at the cafeteria was decently priced and discount was nice
cons: Older coworkers treat younger and new staff horrible. They think they're managers. Low pay. Retail certified techs can make more and the pay caps are higher compared to the hospital. Not many full time positions and then schedule part time and per diem more at times.

review_title: Great place to work depending on your career track
job_title: Patient Care Assistant (PCA) in Bethlehem, PA
pros: Being a PCA at St. Lukes has many benefits considering the position is entry-level. They train you from the ground up and do not need any certifications. Furthermore, if you are interested in the medical field, it is a great place to get experience and provided means of higher education as St. Lukes's is willing to sponsor your nursing school via St. Lukes School of nursing. The job does provide some good bonuses regarding pay to supersede the base pay.
cons: There are long hours as well as a high turnover rate due to the stresses of the job. Depending on where you work you may run into a difficult patient population or if you underperform at work you may be potentially written up. This can provided additional pressure to always be on top of your work. The hours are often inflexible and you must work certain holidays.

pros: Good culture compared to the competition
cons: Low pay, low raises, no advancement

pros: great benefits and safe job overall
cons: long hours, hard to balance work/life hours

pros: Most of the people in the offices are nice.
cons: Worst group of racists and hateful people you will ever meet. The supervisors will gleefully use the N word, make fun of the handicapped people that work there and make horrible comments to the special needs people working there. If you don't have English as a first language they will ignore you and or make fun of you. Trans people who work there were especially reviled by the engineering supervisors, who, oddly enough, are brothers. When I reported a supervisor for calling my grandson the N word HR called me to a meeting and fired me for poor job performance. A month after receiving an excellent employee review. The hospital in Bethlehem not only tolerates racism, it cultivates it. This starts at the CEO and trickles down. Once during a meet my department director told me my wife dresses inappropriately. When I asked how it was any of his business he said we own you and your family. Horrible, ignorant, racist, homophobic and misogynistic are the tip of the iceberg to describe these people. They all worked together for 30 to 40 years so they get away with their behavior. Oh, they steal your overtime pay as well. In all the years the hospital has been in operation, not one person of color ever worked in engineering, how odd. Avoid this place!!

job_title: Medical Laboratory Technician I (MLT) in Bethlehem, PA

review_title: Growth Opportunities in a People Oriented Position
pros:
Learning how to deal with all types of people - Conflict Resolution
Plenty of growth opportunities
Tons of openings and transfer opportunities
Benefits are good and there are discounts at other establishments available to St. Luke's employees
Sense of pride in helping others in need
cons:
Pay is way lower than it should be and salary raises are very hard to come by, even for hard workers
Hours are not always consistent, you can be on the clock long after your shift is supposed to end due to patients in need
Not a job for sensitive individuals: this can be a stressful environment. Patients can be nasty, emergencies can happen out of nowhere, your coworkers will be stressed as well and may take it out on you, etc. A calm head or at least the ability to cool oneself down goes a long way. 
Must be on HR and your manager constantly for your career developments and job needs. There is too much on their plate to focus on you specifically, so it's on you to be persistent with inquiries about your needs.

review_title: The good and the bad you’d expect from a huge hospital system!
pros: Great healthcare benefits, love my patients, love my supervisor and colleagues, great if you can work independently, clinical support is available when needed, growing fast, no micro-management, use the modalities that work best for you and patients, nice to have internal referral system
cons: Under-competitive pay, upper administration does not come across as transparent and appears to prioritize numbers over ethics at times, communication between departments can be poor, continuing education reimbursement is very low, heavy caseloads and not enough time allotted for supervision/collaborative opportunities, growing pains, punitive “strike” system (applied even if you’re sick regardless of proof), must request time off way in advance

review_title: St. Luke' University Health Network is growing and developing in a positive way.
pros: State of the Art compromised with the Safety of the Patients. Accommodate schedule of the employees when a family or health concerns arise ( In the department that I used to work)
cons:
Need to review salary for seniors. Their experience, knowledge, discipline, responsibility, respect and the loyalty to the mission and vision should to be recognized, not only with words but a deserve good salary . Train new professional and give all of us must to be compensated.
Also, the employees work so hard but only few, the one that take care of paper work and business, take the credits and recognition.

pros: Good benefits, lots of opportunity to move into new career paths, the fellowships for OR ER ICU and OB are great ways to start out in better direction vs med surg and continue to learn and grow as a new nurse, they offer a pension plan.
cons: Terrible management is common, pay is lower than other networks, the nurse residency program is a total waste of time and all it does it lock you in, always short staffed and about the money and not the patients or employees. They do not value you and you are just a number. Cut throat and horrible environment to work in. Always threatened with write ups for dumb things like white boards. Never appreciated or told you do a good job they will eat you alive for that one tiny thing you missed in a crazy hectic day. Nasty nurses and drama central. Nurses literally bickering in front of everyone. This place will burn you out. Finding a good unit with good management etc is not likely.

review_title: Excellent nursing staff, very friendly.  The company, as a whole does not treat their nurses very well.
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Phillipsburg, NJ
pros: Hometown hospital environment to some extent.  There is a handful of good nurses left at the Warren Campus.
cons: When St. Luke's Health Network took over the hospital, the hospital environment changed.  The nurses were given much more demanding workloads without any added incentives or support staff, and the expectations of management became more focused on customer service and "being on stage".  They stopped caring about good nurses and providing genuine and compassionate patient care, and they started pushing nurses to engage in "drive-by-nursing" and rehearse customer service lines.

review_title: Great perks if you're attending nursing school
pros: Great perks like $5,000 to $10,000 tuition remission for the RN to BSN program at Moravian College. Great place to work for if your supersivors are understanding and reasonable. My supervisors on the telemetry floor in the Phillipsburg, NJ branch were great, for the most part. Before switching jobs, I was going to
cons: Depends on which staff members you work with, your temperament, the patients, and more. The pay sucks and some nurses aide moved to NY to work instead.

pros: Even though SLUHN is a large care system, I experience it as a close knit, family-like atmosphere which I prefer over the very cold corporate administrative experience at LVHN. However, I do believe that both systems offer high quality care. Also, its nice to see the network finally ramp up some benefits for the clinical staff even if it has come too late for some.
cons: Benefit package is expensive and not as comprehensive as I wish. Insurance was not accepted in many places. We will be joining with Geisinger in the new year...hoping it will be better. Also, as is very typical of the Lehigh Valley in general, RN pay scales still lag far behind our neighbors down the road in Bucks and Montgomery Counties and Easton Hospital.

review_title: Emergency Dept & Admissions - Patient Access Lead Registrar &Trainer;  QA //  HIM Clinical Data Abstractor- Coding Dept
pros: exposure and experience;   I am grateful for the opportunity and time spent.   I know I witnessed and was a part of something much greater than myself or anyone or anything.
cons: the politics of "business"..... I do not feel as if things were handled fairly, or even handled at all.   There is minimal air to express ideas or question processes;    also, management has poor communication with each other, and would often times give contradictory directives and then waste even more time;    "appeared" as if there was lack of ownership....  and poor communication skills often, regarding work delegation.   Time off and vacations also made this more difficult, along with other things.   So I would like to believe they did the best that they could.

job_title: Mental Health Technician in Bethlehem, PA
pros: Great benefits including cheap insurance. Good tuition reimbursement. Lots of training. Direct deposit. You can pay for lunch with payroll.
cons:
If a nurse doesn’t like you they’ll be out to get you and they’ll do everything they can to get rid of you. Same with doctors and nurses. Doctors do anything they can to get nurses into a mess too. 

As a mental health technician it’s not about the patients it’s about the hierarchy of techs nurses and doctors. Nurses write untrue statements in their reports about you when they don’t like you. 

As for st Luke’s if you have any conservative views stay away because someone hacked my information found out where I worked and sent things I commented on people’s facebook pages to Human Resources. You aren’t allowed to have a private life here and if your political views don’t align with them move over. 

I gave my two weeks notice and they didn’t honor it and wanted me to resign immediately. Awful place to work for.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Bethlehem, PA
pros: Great pay and benefits package
cons: In my department, they don't train new hires properly. They have them sit with someone for a few days and then expect the new hire to know everything and be proficient. I don't know how my manager keeps her job. She is the worst manager I've ever had. Very inadequate. Has no idea what's going on half the time. There is no chance for advancement. HR is a joke. They certainly don't honor seniority. Certain employees sit around texting, surfing the net, watching movies etc while others are expected to keep busy at all times. It's like a 3 ring circus. It's all about who you know.

pros: Some individual providers and staff members are dedicated and make working there better. There are certainly qualified medical professionals that are very skilled and do amazing work.
cons: There are unqualified individuals in overpaid positions. They do not have MBA's and some have the bare minimal education. They are most definitely " players" in the management game. There are non medical managers overseeing big medical areas of operations and they are just unqualified for these positions. Additionally, there are many for-profit activities going on in what is proclaimed to be non- profit medicine. There are major decisions being made by unqualified people. It is very sad. Find another hospital. The management is terrible. They have no regard for patient care or safety. If the bottom line is set: They meet it at all cuts and cost. It is shameful.

pros: Caring attitude of the staff for their patients despite the conditions that they must work in.
cons: The hospital administration find it to be very prudent at cutting costs.  That way ER nurses can work the night shift 7p-7a without any support personnel. This includes Lab Techs, ER Techs,, and a secretary. Plus they can just close a floor and save some bucks too. Their education staff act like its a major inconvenience to give any certification class. They also spare no expense at purchasing the most inexpensive software possible. It crashes frequently.

pros: Good Health Care System but Comp/Benefits below market
cons:
If in IT, join at your own peril. All you will do is vendor management and politics.
All decisions starts and stops with CIO - It's a one man show.
All the management resources are non technical, operational and order takers lacking imagination.
There's no concept of structure, delegation and empowerment to make own decisions, even in Sr. leadership.
There's always a competition among Sr. leadership to be in limelight. Picture how it is when a small piece of bone is thrown to a pack of dogs.
Folks on the ground doing actual work do not get recognized.

pros:
Hours were appropriate, never worked weekends because it was a PCP office, able to get off for personal matters/vacations with ease.
I found that communicating with anyone in the network (which occurred multiple times a day) to be a pleasant and respectful interaction.
If there was an issue/concern in the office and you brought it up to your supervisor, it would absolutely be taken care of in a timely manner.  My immediate supervisor, the doctors, and all my coworkers were helpful, respectful, and genuinely good people who I wish I could have worked with longer.
cons: Pay wasn't the best for the amount of work we were responsible for on a daily basis. Understaffed and needed more employees to separate duties appropriately.

pros: Great hospital at Monroe,flexible schedule, director is the best!!!  Great co workers.  Beautiful hospital.
cons: Worst Human Resources department EVER!!!  Directors have less to do with who is on their unit HR has too much power!  Other than HR needing to be completely restaffed with people who actually care about their employees,  there are no other complaints!! Would be the perfect place if it weren’t for the HR office on a power trip!

review_title: Potentially promising, yet realistically, extremely disapponting.
pros: The potential to be a good workplace exists, but in no way is it being utilized or implemented.
cons: Low wages compared to other regional facilities.  A CEO that shows no connection to the employees.  Too much expansion in too little a time frame.  Penny wise and dollar foolish.

job_title: Patient Care Assistant in Easton, PA
pros: I love the people I work with, we all do really care about our patients and about each other,
cons: You will burn out quickly because there is a high turnover rate. St.Luke's isn't competitive in their pay and they don't really listen to their employees. They are very understaffed and won't hire more people because it keeps costs low. All they are about are their reviews from patients so they can keep winning more titles.

review_title: Great place to work...if you never need to take sick time
pros: Overall morale is good, and most of the employees are like a team, even when from different departments.  The company does what it can during hard times to avoid pay cuts, layoffs and reductions in health insurance benefits.  Individuals and departments are recognized for outstanding work, and they make everyone feel important.  Many of upper management are approachable and interact with staff that is "lower on the totem pole".
cons: Department managers are given too much authority with not much oversight of their actions.  During disputes, Human Resources always sides with the managers, believing their word over that of the lowly staff members they may be trampling all over.  If a manager treats one of his/her staff unfairly, there is no unbiased third party to turn to.  Worst of all is the fact that someone high up (even HR claims to not know who it is) decided to make rigid rules concerning attendance, which take precedence over all over things, no matter how important those other things are.  The rules are followed to the letter...to the extent that you are punished as severely for being a minute late as you would be for being an hour late. And heaven forbid a nurse catches a virus and wants to protect her patients and fellow workers from it by staying home for a day or two.  If she doesn't pay her doctor (which would be a St Luke's physician, if she wants it to be covered by the health benefits) for an unnecessary visit for a virus or other self-limiting ailment, she is in danger of severe punishment.  Sure, they give you lots of sick time...but you can't use it without losing your job!  If you have more than one "occurrence" of sick time without a doctor's excuse within 90 days, you get a third step corrective action right away, no matter what!  Who can drive to the doctor when they are throwing up all day with a virus the doctor can't do anything about?  It is illogical and completely unfair to the workers and their patients.

pros: Great opportunity for anyone who wants to become a nurse.  The oldest hospital based nursing school and no matter what your role is as a full time employee you can go to the nursing school for FREE if you have completed your prerequisites, apply and get in.  This is an awesome opportunity.  Tuition reimbursement for full-time nurses to further their education is also very generous.
cons: As with many hospital systems, staffing shortages are always an issue.  Pay raises are on the lower side as compared to other hospitals.

review_title: Nutrition Service Aide Okay PT Job
job_title: Nutrition Services Aide in Bethlehem, PA
pros: Good job for a high school or college student. Always easy to find hours (if you want them)
cons:
Pretty heavy schedule, when I was in high school I would work 6 days a week because lack of staff. Some managers can be very belittling to you, even if you know more about a specific issue than them. 
Limited hours, you either work 6 am to 3 pm or 4-8 pm.

pros: Promotions are always yours for the taking. The salary is competitive. The community is not a bad one.
cons: Big organization with a broad sweeping view to the future. I wish we were more organized clear in our efforts. Maybe instead of doing a lot of things average do just a few things great.

pros: They are a growing company and are focused on patient care.  Hospitals are staffed with quality doctors.  I would take my family to their hospital.
cons: My experience is with the EMS department.  It's manager has had at least 1 DWI and for some reason they keep him around.  He makes promises that he won't follow through with.

pros: Work-life balance, nice people, exciting to be part of the fast growing healthcare industry. Decent benefits package. Nice building to work in.
cons: Dead end job. Promotions happen all the time in other departments, but rarely in the finance department.  Also, I could get a higher salary for the same work elsewhere.

pros: Benefits, coworkers, overall good feel type of environment. It made you feel good going to work every day and seeing people who treated you like family. The doctors there are wonderful and the fact that there are residents is very helpful.
cons: There are not many downsides to working at St. Lukes, I enjoyed my time there greatly. I'd say the only downside is the pay is not very great.

pros: Coworkers that work in my immediate department are for the most part easy to work with.
cons: Apethetic work force. Favortism. Nepotism. Management more focused on getting thier bonuses and growing the corperation than managing thier resources well. Employees forced to travel all over the Lehigh Valley to cover shifts. Poor allocation of resources and planning and execution of thier expantion across the valley

job_title: Mental Health Technician in Allentown, PA
pros: Very friendly staff , good pay can ask for more hours they need the staff ASAP.
cons: Won't give you a job if you're a cigarette smoker.

pros: Not many, intimate small setting. Most people know each other.  Has the potential for being a nice small community hospital.
cons: A CEO, (Rick Anderson) that is completely out of touch with his employees. He made over $1.3 million in 2011.    No network contribution to the mandatory "work wear rule."  They choose the color, style, vendor, and they make it mandatory that the "St Lukes logo" is on your work wear.  So if you work more than one job, you can't utilize your work clothes.

review_title: My experience has been overall very positive working here.
pros: St. Lukes has always been known as a community hospital.  People are friendly and they try to promote a positive work environment.  They are continually expanding, so job stability is good. Overall, a great place to work.
cons: Because they are expanding,  sometimes they expect employees to travel to different locations. The salary is not as high as other local hospitals.

job_title: RN Field Case Manager in Allentown, PA
pros: Make my own schedule..after patient visits done, can work at home..good medical plan..mileage paid for nursing visits
cons: On call overnight shifts once every three months with minimal pay..1 to 9pm shifts every other week all over Lehigh Valley..only two weeks vacation a year..sometimes inconsiderate schedulers and clinical coordinators

job_title: Nutrition Service Aide in Bethlehem, PA
pros: Flexibility, shift differential pay, patient to service contact, patient surveys-it is nice that they do them to see how they can better their service
cons: equipment, follow through, lack of employees, lack of senior management understanding when a person cannot work especially during a horrific thunderstorm, favoritism

pros: Everyone is very friendly. I liked how seriously many employees took PCRAFT and addressing the patients.
cons: You have to be in the network for a year before receiving an incentive bonus. Enjoyed my time with the network but that made me feel undervalued. Benefits could be better. Copays can be pricy.

pros: Some solid co-workers, specialists and generalists. Nice newer hospitals, no storage of money in having top of the line diagnostics.
cons: Physician administrative leadership is deceptive, condescending, self enamored and very deceitful. Promises made almost never kept. Weak specialties in several areas. Grew way to quickly and in some. Cases hired/bought "warm bodies" making exorbitant incomes. Several .great physicians vaporized in past 1-2 yrs with trail of cover up receipt and slander. Would avoid employment arrangement. Risky

review_title: Very Good. Wouldn't want to work anywhere else, I love my job even though i'm reserve.
pros: My boss is awesome, I get to help people when things are tough and scary...
cons: Benefits cost more now, the upper management can be really tough to please...

review_title: Absolutely amazing culture. Great people, great working environment. Nothing bad to say.
pros: The people, opportunities for advancement, great location, educational culture (everyone is happy to teach you as long as you are willing to learn)
cons: No cons at this time. Management is great to work with and I have gained so much experience. I am lucky to have the opportunity to work for such a great organization.

job_title: Practice Administrator II in Bethlehem, PA
pros: Great values.  The organization puts the patients and employees first.  Leadership is approachable and encourages feedback.
cons: Since the network is rapidly growing and expanding,  compensation doesn't keep up with the added responsibilities (added providers, staff, & locations) or with what is considered fair market value in comparison to industry standards.

pros: I received a paycheck every two weeks.
cons: Was shocked to find out how this non profit operated and what they allowed their employees to put on company credit cards, most time with no receipts...dog bones, swim goggles, alcohol, spa treatments, daily visits to restaurants, gift cards, filling up their gas tanks, etc.. and the nepotism and cronyism, not getting bids just hiring their friends and family at any cost.

job_title: Epic Willow Credentialed Trainer in Jim Thorpe, PA
pros: Great place to work during training, go-live and the other employees were always professional, courteous and helpful. Everyone worked as a team.
cons: Transition team has not looked out for the employees reaching the end of their contracts. They have provided no information or guidance.

pros: Good pay, benefits and work with a strong clinical support team. The level/ quality of the medicine practiced is good... (the admin is another story.)
cons: Has grown too large, too fast. Moderate disconnect between admin and clinical staff.

pros: Very good benefits, easy job if you’re able to multitask with ease.
cons: Don’t know how to train properly, too many call offs , the ones who are giving up their personal free time to fill in get no kudos or appreciation. Low pay!

pros: Easy to pick up hours if you need a boost. Decent atmosphere to work in.
cons: Refuse to make full time positions available to avoid having to pay for the benefits, but will schedule you to work full time hours. Very little appreciation for the employees that go above and beyond their normal duties. They don't pay as well as other hospitals in the area.

pros: One of the best reasons to work at St Lukes Hospital is because it is a great working environment and it is full of hard working nurses and doctors trying to meet their patients needs.
cons: The only con there can be is the working hours because it gets really busy a lot of the time, specially during the holidays.

pros: co workers and environment are incredible. st lukes is a magnet hospital-they truly invest et show concern for their employees.
cons: lower salary than other local hospitals.

pros: Very positive atmosphere and managers are caring about their employees.
cons: Challenges are the pay and getting promotions.

pros: I love the colleagues I work with and communicate with daily. There are challenging cases. There is room to advance in your career and get involved in many committees

review_title: Great hospital network to work for

pros: Great co-workers and the network is excellent at continued education opportunities.  The work schedule is reasonably for the department I am involved in.

pros: Well led. Not afraid to take risks. Focused on best practice medicine

pros: Great teamwork, great  management. Fair pay and great benefits.  A lot of OT opportunities.

review_title: Don't get paid for what you do.
